System

​

Metanthropes RPG utilizes a d100 system. Each type of action attempted by a Player, or the Narrator, depends on a 100-sided die roll to determine its outcome. Two ten-sided dice are rolled simultaneously, one representing the double digits of the roll, and the other representing the single digits. Players compare the outcome of their rolls with the Stats of their Protagonist (which are always in the form of a % percentage) to determine whether their roll is a success or a failure. When attempting a d100 roll, you are successful when you have rolled the number of your Stat used and below. Whenever your result is above your Stat used, then the roll is considered a failure.

How a d100 roll works

The Narrator asks me to make a roll on behalf of my Protagonist. My required Stat score is 50% and my dice result was 50. I barely made it, but it was a successful attempt. In case I have rolled 51 and above, my result would have been a failure.

 

Ten-sided dice (single digits only) are rolled to determine other numerical outcomes, such as the Duration of an activated effect, the total Damage inflicted by a source and others. When a roll of 10 occurs, the 10 counts towards the outcome of the roll; the die is then re-rolled, and the new outcome is added to the total. This process is repeated for each result of 10, any number of times, before the final sum of the roll can be determined. This effect is called the “Splash 10” effect.

 

How a d10 roll works

A roll which includes 2d10 (two ten-sided dice) is asked of my Protagonist, to determine the total number of Targets of an effect. My roll’s result was 2 and 10, the Splash 10 Effect commences and the 10 is added to the total and then re-rolled. The second result was another 10, so the process repeats, and the third result was a 3. My total result of that roll was 25 (2 + 10 + 10 + 3).

 

Whenever any numerical values need to be multiplied or divided, resulting in decimals, the result is always rounded up.

 Levels of Success & Failure

 

Not all success or failures are considered equal. The measure by which a roll succeeds or fails is dictated by its Levels of Success, or Levels of Failure. These are determined by the difference of the number of the Stat (%) used for the roll and the outcome of the roll. Levels of Success or Failure are always calculated in tens, and single digits are ignored. For every 10% the roll outcome is below the Stat used, a Level of Success (✔️️) is accumulated, and for every 10% the roll outcome is above the Stat used, a Level of Failure (❌) is accumulated. 

 

Additional ✔️✔️️ result to a more desired outcome, while additional ❌ will lead to unwanted outcomes. A roll’s result which is below the number of the Stat used, but less than 10% is considered a Success without any Levels of Success (🟩), while a roll’s result which is above the number of the Stat used, but less than 10% is considered a Failure, without any Levels of Failure (🟥).

 

Simple success & simple failure

My Protagonist attempts a roll with a Stat score of 50%. If my roll’s result is anywhere between 49 and 41, it would result to 🟩. If my roll’s result is anywhere between 51 and 59, it would result to 🟥.

 

How Levels of Success are accumulated

My Protagonist attempts a roll with a Stat score of 50%. My roll’s result was a 25, therefore I accumulated ✔️✔️(50-25 = 25, ignoring the single digits). In case I would have rolled 20, I would have accumulated ✔️✔️✔️️ instead (50-20=30).

 

How Levels of Failure are accumulated

My Protagonist attempts a roll with a Stat score of 22%. My roll’s result was a 60, therefore I accumulated ❌❌❌ (22-60 = -38, ignoring the single digits). In case I would have rolled 62, I would have accumulated ❌❌❌❌ instead (22-62=-40).

 

Besides dictating the degree of success or failure or a roll, certain numbers of ✔️️ are required in some activations of Metapowers to unlock further effects, while crossing the threshold of a specific number of ❌will have fixed results. The Narrator may ask for a specific amount of ✔️️ for a specific action to commence, while additionally the Narrator may warn a player that reaching a specific number of ❌, will have as result specific misfortunes happening. The following table outlines how additional ✔️️ or ❌ may affect in-game the impact of any given roll. Use this table as a reference, but results may vary according to the situation in-game. For more about Critical Successes and Critical Failures, read below.

 

Successes & Failures table

​Bonuses & Penalties

 

The Narrator may choose to impose a circumstantial Bonus or Penalty on any roll attempted, befitting the situation under which the action is attempted. A Bonus is applied on a favored roll, while a Penalty on a disfavored roll. Bonuses and Penalties apply to a singular roll, and after the roll is made all Bonuses and Penalties are removed.

 

A Bonus on a roll may range from +10% to +100%, and a Penalty on a roll may range from -10% to -100%. Bonuses above +50% are considered plot devising interventions, while Penalties below -50% are actions which go against all odds, doomed to fail on most occasions.

 

In the event a roll is affected by more than one Bonus, only the highest Bonus in value is applied, and the rest are ignored. Similarly, in the event a roll is affected by more than one Penalty, only the lowest Penalty in value is applied, and the rest are ignored. However, if a roll is affected by both a Bonus and a Penalty, subtract the latter from the former to determine the circumstantial modifier which will ultimately affect the roll. The following table showcases which Bonuses and which Penalties can be applied to rolls, based on the complexity of the action attempted in the situation the roll is involved in.

 

 Rolling with multiple Bonuses

The Narrator informs me that my attempted roll, due to various circumstances in-game has a + 40% and a + 10% Bonus. Only the highest Bonus is considered, therefore I consider only the + 40% Bonus. 

 

 Rolling with multiple Penalties

The Narrator informs me that my attempted roll, due to various circumstances in-game has a – 20% and a – 30% Penalty. Only the  lowest Penalty are considered, therefore I consider only the -30% Penalty. 

 

 Rolling with multiple Bonuses and Penalties

The Narrator informs me that my attempted roll, due to various circumstances in-game has a + 40% and a + 10% Bonus, while additionally the roll has a – 20% and a – 30% Penalty. Only the highest Bonus and the lowest Penalty are considered, therefore I consider only the + 40% Bonus and the -30% Penalty. Since the roll is affected by both a Bonus and a Penalty, I subtract the Penalty from the Bonus (40-30 = 10), and therefore the final modifier for that roll is a + 10% Bonus.

 

Bonuses & Penalties table

 

​🤞 Destiny

 

In Metanthropes, Destiny (🤞) is a resource which Players can spend to reroll any roll with an undesirable outcome, and even save their Protagonists from dying. Each Protagonist starts the game with a predetermined number of Destiny and is awarded additional Destiny at the beginning of each new Scene, based on their role-play.

 

A Player may spend any number of Destiny on a dice roll, but only the last outcome is considered valid. Players can spend any amount of Destiny by rerolling any number of their rolls attempted. A Player may spend one Destiny to reroll any d100 roll, or any roll that involves any number of d10 dice. In case of the latter, when multiple d10 dice are involved, with each Destiny spent, all d10 dice are rerolled, ignoring the previous sum. Players cannot spend their Destiny to force other Characters to reroll that way. Lastly, Destiny is also rewarded at the special roll outcomes of 001% and 100%. For more about in Critical Success & Critical Failure read the following section.

 

Destiny and d100 rolls

I attempted a d100 roll with a Stat score of 75% and the result was 80. Knowing that I can do much better than that, I spend a Destiny and reroll, with the new outcome being 95. Still not satisfied, I keep on pushing my luck, and the following result was 55, accumulating ✔️✔️. Satisfied with that outcome, I keep that result and I withdraw a total of two Destiny ( 🤞🤞) from my Destiny total.

 

Destiny and d10 rolls

I attempted a roll which involves five d10 dice. My result was 1, 3, 6, 5, and 5 for a total of 20. Feeling that I can do better, I spend a Destiny and reroll all of the dice involved, and the new outcome was 2, 2, 6, 4, and 1 for an even worse total of 15 this time. I decide to keep pushing my luck, and my next result was 5, 5, 7, 8, and 5 for a total of 30. Satisfied with that outcome, I keep that result and I withdraw a total of two Destiny ( 🤞🤞) from my Destiny total.

For more about how to gain Destiny, visit here.

For more about  Destiny  and Metapowered effects visit here.

For more about Protagonist Death and Destiny visit here.

 

 Critical Success & Critical Failure

A roll of a 001% (00 and 1) is a Critical Success, and a roll of 100 (00 and 10) is a Critical Failure.  Whenever a Character rolls a Critical Success and a Critical Failure alike, that Character is  rewarded with a 🤞 (one Destiny), but a Character cannot spend  a 🤞to reroll a Critical Failure. A Critical Success is always considered a Success, ignoring all Penalties, circumstances in-game, and the score of the Stat used, and automatically accumulates ten Levels of Success (10 *✔️). A Critical Failure is always considered a Failure, ignoring all Bonuses and the score of the Stat used, and automatically accumulates ten Levels of Failure (10 *❌).

 

A Critical Success

During a violent prison riot, I decide that my Protagonist will attempt to calm the inmates by devising a clever speech. My roll's outcome is 001, a Critical Success. As a result, my Protagonist's speech proves to be a jaw-dropping motivational speech, that instantly ceases all violent acts and even persuades some inmates to return to their cells on their own accord.

 

A Critical Failure

My Protagonist is the driver during a high-stakes car chase. The Narrator requests a roll  to avoid crushing the car. My roll’s outcome is 100, a Critical Failure. The Narrator describes that during a daring maneuver, my Protagonist fumbles and the result is catastrophic. The vehicle crashes into a loaded truck, completely wrecking the car and resulting all aboard receiving terrible damage and medical conditions.

 

VS Roll​

 

Often in Metanthropes RPG, actions are performed which involve other Characters who may be unwilling to be subjected to the desired effect, and they are given a chance to defend themselves. The outcome of contested attempt is calculated by an opposing roll, called a Versus, or VS roll. Each Character involved makes a Stat roll determined by the Narrator (or by the effect’s designated Stat used in case of the Activation of a Metapower, Combo, or a Possession). The Stat rolled can be the same, or a different Stat can be used for each of both contesting parties. A Character who initiates the VS roll can do so against one single target, or multiple. The defending party may choose not to make their roll, allowing the initiator to win the VS roll without a struggle.

 

The Character who initiated the VS roll attempts the roll first and calculates if the result is successful or not (🟩 or 🟥) and if any ✔️ or ❌were accumulated. Then the defending Character involved in the VS roll proceeds to calculate the same.  If the initiator of the VS roll was successful (🟩 or with any additional ✔️) and the defending party was not (🟥 or with any additional ❌), then the action was successful, and the defending party becomes subjected to the effect.

 

If both parties accumulated any number of  ✔️️, if the initiator of the VS roll has accumulated more  ✔️️ than the defending Character, then the action was successful, and the defending party becomes subject to the effect. However, each  ✔️️ accumulated by the defending Character removes one  ✔️️ accumulated by the initiator of the VS roll. If the defending Character’s roll instead resulted in a failure (🟥), or accumulated any number of ❌, then only the amount of ✔️accumulated by the initiator are considered. In the case of VS rolls which involve multiple Characters as the defending party, then each ✔️ accumulated by all defending Characters, remove one ✔️ accumulated by the Initiator of the VS roll.

 

VS roll with both parties being Successful

My Protagonist and an NPC are caught up in a dispute. The Narrator declares that the dispute in-game must be settled with a VS roll between my Protagonist and the NPC. Since I initiated the contested roll, I make my Stat roll first. My roll’s result accumulated ✔️✔️✔️✔️. Subsequently, the Narrator makes the appropriate Stat roll for the NPC. The Narrator’s roll outcome accumulated ✔️. As a result, I manage to win the VS roll by accumulating a total of ✔️✔️✔️ (one ✔️is removed from my total, due to the NPC’s success in the VS roll).

 

In case of a tie (an equal amount of ✔️ or in case both were successful🟩, without accumulating any additional ✔️), the roll which is closest to their appropriate Stat wins the contest. In the rare occurrence where both outcomes are equally distant from their respective Stats, it is considered a perfect tie. In that case, both parties involved gain 🤞 (one Destiny) and the VS roll is performed from the beginning. 

 

VS roll with a tie result

The Narrator declares a dispute between my Protagonist and an NPC, must be resolved via a VS roll. I attempt my appropriate Stat roll first and accumulate✔️✔️✔️✔️. The defending party rolls and also accumulates ✔️✔️✔️✔️. Since both Characters had the same number of accumulated ✔️✔️✔️✔️, the roll which is closest to their appropriate Stat wins the contest. My Protagonists appropriate Stat is 54 and the roll made had a result of 10: my exact outcome was 44 (54 – 10 = 44) . The NPC's appropriate Stat was 68, and roll result was 24, with an exact outcome of 44 (68 – 24 = 44), a perfect tie! As a result, both Characters gain one 🤞, and the VS roll is performed from the beginning.

  

  In case both parties involved in a VS roll want to spend Destiny (🤞) to reroll their initial rolls, the initiator of the VS rolls always declares and spends any amount of Destiny for consecutive rerolls, up until they decide to keep their last roll. Afterwards it is the defending Character’s turn to spend any amount of Destiny, up until they decide to keep their last roll. They do not need to know the result of each other unless the Narrator states otherwise. The VS roll is resolved with the last roll each Character kept after they were done spending their Destiny rerolls.

 

Whenever the defending Character is involved in a VS roll, that roll is always considered a Free Roll for that Character and costs no Action slot.

 

Fore more about Free Rolls and Action slots, visit here.

 

Characteristics & Stats

 

There are three Characteristics in Metanthropes: Body, Mind and Soul. Each of them has three sub-categories called Stats. The Stats of the Body are: Endurance, Power and Reflexes. The Stats of the Mind are: Creativity, Manipulation and Perception. The Stats of the Soul are: Awareness, Consciousness and Will.

 

A Character with 0% Body: receives the Condition Immobilized, cannot attempt any rolls which involve any Stat of the Body, and all activated, and permanent effects generated by that Character by any Stat of the Body of that Character immediately end their Duration. A Character with 0% Body: receives the Condition Immobilized, cannot attempt any rolls which involve any Stat of the Body, and all activated, and permanent effects generated by that Character by any Stat of the Body of that Character immediately end their Duration.

 

Body

 Body is the Characteristic which defines a Character’s constitution, physical prowess, and physique.

A Character with 0% Body: receives the Condition Immobilized, cannot attempt any rolls which involve any Stat of the Body, [🛡️ Hardened. 💀 Burned]

Endurance

 ·         Endurance determines a Character’s stamina, health, and vigor.

🛡️ Fortified

💀 Bone Injury

   

A Character with 0% Endurance: receives the Condition: Pain 3.

​

Power

·         Power determines a Character’s strength, striking effectiveness, and physical explosiveness. 

​

Power determines a Character’s strength, striking effectiveness, and physical explosiveness.

 

 🛡️ Empowered

💀 Muscle Injury

 

A Character may attempt a Power roll by spending their Extra Action or Main Action to push, pull, lift, or toss any target. The amount of  ✔️ ️ accumulated, determine the total number of the Weight of the target that can be handled this way, as seen in the following table. The Push/Pull filter includes how many Hexagons can move per  ✔️ ️ accumulated, with targets with Weight below 10 applying a Bonus to the roll. The Lift filter includes how many  ✔️ ️ are required in order to lift and carry the target, with targets with Weight below 10 applying a Bonus to the roll. The Toss filter includes how many Hexagons you can hurl a target with each  ✔️ ️ accumulated, for targets of Weight 10 and below, and how many  ✔️ ️ accumulated are required to Toss targets of Weight above 10

 Jump…climb

 A Character with 0% Power: Drops everything held, cannot carry anything, if they are wearing any Armor - they cannot move in the Grid.

  

Reflexes

 ·         Reflexes determines a Character’s agility, motor skills and balance.  

​ 

 🛡️ Hastened

💀 Skin Injury

 

A Character with 0% Reflexes: cannot attempt any Reactions.

 

Mind

 Mind is the Characteristic which defines a Character’s brainpower, problem solving and innovative thoughts.

A Character with 0% Mind: cannot attempt any type of Actions during their Turn.  [🛡️ Sharpened. 💀 Disconnected]

 

Creativity

 

​         Creativity determines a Character’s imagination, expression, and handiwork. 

 

 🛡️ Inspired

💀 Wobbly

 

A Character with 0% Creativity: cannot attempt any Focused Actions or Multi-Actions.

 

Manipulation

·         Manipulation determines a Character’s persuasiveness, charisma, and social engineering skills. 

​ 

 🛡️ Articulated

💀 Confused

   

A Character with 0% Manipulation: cannot communicate with any way.

​ 

Perception

 

    Perception determines a Character’s observatory, evaluative and calculative capabilities.​ 

 🛡️ Alerted

💀 Disoriented

A Character with 0% Perception: receives all the Sense Lost Conditions.

 

Soul

 Soul is the Characteristic which defines a Character’s conviction, spiritual prowess, and mettle.

 

A Character with 0% Soul: receive the Condition: Unconscious 4.

 

Awareness

 

·         Awareness determines a Character’s empathy, intuition, and instinctual responses.

 🛡️ Focused

💀 Bewildered

   

A Character with 0% Awareness: believes everything they are told.

 

Consciousness

 

·         Consciousness determines a Character’s recollection, subconscious processing, and sanity.​

 

 🛡️ Awakened

💀 Demented

   

A Character with 0% Consciousness: receives the Condition Unconscious.

Willpower

 

​ ·         Willpower determines a Character’s courage, discipline, and confidence. 

 ​

 🛡️ Determined

💀 Terrorized

 

A Character with 0% Willpower: Runs away or cowers in fear.

 

 

Perks

 

​ 

Perks in Metanthropes represent a Character’s background training, professions, developed talents and practices. Perks give access to specific techniques, information, fields of study, and technical know-how on order to use certain Possessions. Furthermore, Perks offers additional depth and development to a Protagonist, which differs from their Metapowered arsenal.

 

Perks are categorized into Knowledge and Skills. Knowledge refers to abilities developed through studying theories, learning thesis and theorems, and performing simulations and experiments. Skills refer to abilities that develop through practical appliance, repetition and practicing them in the field.

 

Knowledge

 

Each level of a Perk: Knowledge, offers the Character unlocking or progressing it a field of study. A field of study is a specialization the Character has within the greater field of Knowledge. Each Knowledge listed below offers a list of available fields of study, but a Player may, in collaboration with the Narrator, come up with their own fields of study. Having a Knowledge at higher level not only gives access to further fields of study, but also increases the Character's overall mastery of a certain Perk. Using some Possessions or making certain computations in-game requires having a specific knowledge level. Characters attempting to use an Item, or a technique without having attained the required Knowledge level, cannot attempt that roll. At the Narrator’s discretion, Protagonists who have spent significant amount of time learning something in-game, may attempt a Knowledge-based roll with a Penalty.

Skills

 

Each level of any Skill offers a Character access to new techniques, and the know-how needed to use specific Gadgets, Weapons or Vehicles without Penalties. A Character attempting a roll which requires a Skill at a certain level, without the required Skill level may still attempt a roll, but a -10% Penalty is applied for each missing levels of Skills required. At the Narrator’s discretion, in the event a Character has the Perk Athletics, Operation or Weapons at a certain level, but not the level required to perform that technique or use that Possession, the Narrator may allow the Character to attempt Skill-based rolls with a reduced Penalty.

 

 

How lack of  the appropriate Skill level applies Reduction

I want my Protagonist to use a machinegun riffle (which requires the Skill: Weapons at level 3). My Protagonist's Skill: Weapons level is only 1. Therefore, I may attempt using that Weapon, but with a – 20% Penalty on my roll.

​

A Metanthropes Session consists of Scenes, where Protagonists and NPCs interact through dialogue and individual actions to shape the story. Such Scenes are not turn-based, and Characters can interact in real-time as actors in a play. However, whenever any number of Characters involved in a Scene want to perform opposing or contradicting actions, with different interests and conflicting purposes, then a turn-based Action Scene commences. During an Action Scene, in-game time comes to a halt, and Character actions become subject to a specific set of rules presented in this section.

 

Initiative

 

During an Action Scene, Characters act in Turns.  The order by which each Character may act is determined by an Initiative roll. Initiative is what sets the play order for all Characters involved in an Action Scene. When the Narrator calls for Initiative, all Characters involved in the Action Scene proceed to make a Reflexes roll. The Character with the most accumulated ✔️ will play first, followed by the one with the second most ✔️, up until the Character with the least ✔️ has played. Then the Character with the least ❌ will play, followed by the one with the second least ❌, up until the Character with the most ❌ has played as well. In case of a Critical Success or a Critical Failure, the Character who made the roll is awarded a Destiny as usual during such rolls, and accumulates 10 *✔️  in case of a Critical Success or 10 * ❌  in case of a Critical Failure. There is no additional reward or punishment at Critical Rolls during Initiative.

 

In case multiple Characters enter the Initiative with the same outcome, who ever has the highest Reflexes plays first, followed by the one with the second highest and so on.  In case any Characters who have the same Initiative outcome, and both have the exact same number at their Stat who was involved at rolling Initiative: then both Characters receive a Destiny and make an additional Initiative roll between them to determine who goes first between them. Some Characters who might have Metapowers such as 6th Sense, might roll Initiative with a different Stat, other than Reflexes.

 

Example of Initiative

Four Characters (A,B,C,D) are involved in an Action Scene, and roll for Initiative. Their result are ✔️for Character A, ✔️✔️for Character B, and  ❌ for both Character C and D. Characters C and D both had the same result, but Character D has a higher Reflexes score. The final order of play is the following: Character B, Character A, Character D, and Character C. 

 

Turn

 

A Turn begins whenever it is a Character’s turn to play during an Action Scene. A Turn’s duration in-game is usually a few seconds, unless the Narrator states otherwise.  Read below the segment “During my Turn” for more about what can be accomplished during a Turn.

 

Round

 

When all Characters involved in the Action Scene completed their Turn, a Round is complete. A full Action Scene Round lasts up to thirty seconds, although the in-game time of each Round is largely dependent on the nature of the actions undertaken by the Characters and the situation in-game.

 

Cycle

 

A Cycle consists of two consecutive Rounds within an Action Scene. Following the end of the first Round, all Characters involved in the Action Scene play again, using the same Initiative score. After the second Round is completed, the first Cycle of the Action Scene ends. After each Cycle ends, each Character involved in the Action Scenes proceeds to make a subsequent Reflexes roll to determine the next Cycle’s Initiative order. When the next Cycle is over, repeat the process until the Narrator declares the Action Scene is over.

 

It is possible for a Character to increase their position of the Initiative order of play during their Turn. That can be accomplished, for example, by increasing one's Reflexes score during their Turn, and bypassing this way the previous Character's total Initiative score. When that occurs, during the next Round of the same Cycle, that Character will increase their position to the Initiative order.

   

During My Turn

 

During a Turn, a Character can Roleplay,  perform a Movement (move my Character around, and interact with the environment), and attempt Actions (anything which involves dice rolling). Roleplaying during my Turn during an Action Scene is different than Roleplaying during any other Scene; it should not be extensive or highly elaborate, as there is less time to engage in dialogue while performing other actions and moving around. Players are encouraged to allow for minimal “free Roleplay” during their Turns, limited to a few lines when it is my Turn, and only a couple outside of my Turn, within the Round. However, in the event I want my Protagonist to engage in more extensive Roleplay during my Scene, I can choose to forgo doing Actions, or Movement, or even my whole Turn, at the Narrator’s discretion.

 

Wait

 

In the case a Character is not ready to play their Turn right away, but they do not want to lose their involvement in the Round, they can choose to Wait. By doing so, they temporarily forgo performing Actions and Movement, and the next Character in the Initiative order plays. After that Character, the Character who have chosen to Wait can declare to the Narrator that they want their Wait to end, and join in and play their Turn. When choosing the option of Wait, a Character cannot perform any type of Action (except for their Reaction, see below for more about Reactions), nor any Movement, and they are only limited to a few lines of "free Roleplay".  After that Round, the next time their time comes to play during this Cycle, they can play their Turn at its normal spot in the Initiative order or perform Wait again. In the case multiple Characters want to end their Wait and play at the same time, the Character with the highest Initiative plays first, followed by the Character who has the second-highest Initiative, and so on. The two last Characters in an Initiative order cannot perform the Wait option. In case any of two last Characters in the Initiative order begin their Turn, whoever has chosen to Wait and did not play up to that point, will lose their Turns during this Round.

​

Actions

 

Action in Metanthropes is anything that involves making a d100 roll (and sometimes subsequently d10 rolls as well). During each of my Turns, I have access to three different slots of Actions. A Main Action, an Extra Action, and a Reaction. Whatever a Character mainly attempts during a Turn, spends the Main Action slot. A Character's Extra Action slot can be spent on undemanding, simple tasks. The Reaction slot is reserved as an answer to other Characters’ actions. A Reaction is the only type of Action that can be played during another Character’s Turn. 

 

Additionally, an activity that require a Character's absolute focus and additional time to be activated, might turn into a Focused Action.  A Focused Action requires spending all Action slots and a Character's Movement in order to commence. The exact time a Focused Action might require to complete varies, according to the task at hand, from a Full-Turn, to a Cycle, or more. 

 

At the beginning of each new Round, I refresh all my Action slots. Lastly, the Narrator can offer a Character any number of Free Rolls that do not take any of the mentioned slots in order for the Character to perform minor feats not worthy of an Action slot. One such roll is always the defending Character’s roll in case of a VS roll. Unless specifically stated, the Narrator has the final say as to which Character’s Action should take the Main Action, Extra Action, Focused Action, or Reaction slot, or if they should take no slot at all and be offered a Free Roll instead.

 

Main Action

 

A Main Action can be any type of action which requires a successful dice roll, but also sufficient time and concentration to perform. A Main Action requires some concentration, but not the entire focus of a Character, enabling them to move and potentially do additional things while still performing the Main Action. Most Stat rolls, Metapowered activations, uses of Possessions, and most type of Attacks require spending the Main Action slot.  The Main Action slot can be turned to a Multi-Action, whenever a Character wants to attempt multiple Main Actions during a single Turn by reducing the efficiency of each roll.

 

Multi-Action

 

Characters may choose to split their Main Action into multiple Main Actions, called a Multi-Action. A Character can perform the same Main Action multiple times or attempt different Main Actions with a successful Multi-Action. Only a Main Action slot can be turned into Multi-Action, not any other type of Action slots.

 

Whenever a Character is attempting a Multi-Action, apply a – 10% reduction on all Main Action rolls attempted by that Character this Turn, for each number of total Main Actions attempted. There is no limit to the number of additional Main Actions a Character can include as part of a Multi-Action, but in the event any of the Stat rolls involved drops below 1% due to the Multi-Action reduction, then that Character cannot perform that Multi-Action.

 

How Multi-Action reductions function

Attempting two Main Actions as part of a Multi-Action, will impose a reduction by – 20% to both rolls. Attempting a Multi-Action with three Main Actions will impose a – 30% reduction to all three rolls. Attempting a Multi-Action with four Main Actions will impose a – 40% reduction on all four rolls, and so on.

 

The reduction imposed by the Multi-Action is not considered a Penalty. Attempting a Multi-Action while having a Penalty on any of the rolls attempted, will cause the reductions of the roll to stack, and additionally reduce the Character’s chance of success.

 

How Penalties and reduction from Multi-Action stack

 A Character attempts a Multi-Action which includes two Main Actions and the second of those rolls has a – 20% Penalty, then that Character will attempt the two rolls, the first with a – 20% reduction and the other with a total – 40% reduction (- 20% due to Multi-Action and another – 20% due to the Penalty).

 

A Character attempting a Multi-Action must state the total number of Main Actions to be included in the Multi-Action before attempting any of the rolls. A Character cannot add or remove any number of Main Actions after they have attempted the first. A Character must only state the total number of Actions, allowing to change, or repeat the same Main Actions in case of failing any of them. A Character can choose to forgo attempting any of the number of Main Actions declared to be attempted, and choose different Targets from those originally intended. In the event a Character wants to spend Destiny (🤞) to reroll any of the rolls involved in a Multi-Action, they can do so for each roll individually. In the case they are activating a Metapower or a Combo which requires spending any 🤞 as part of its activation, you must spend the number of 🤞 required for the activation for each number of such actions you want to include in your Multi-Action.

 

How Destiny and Multi-Action works

 A Character attempts to activate a Metapower which requires the expenditure of one Destiny (🤞) as part of its Activation, and activates as a Main Action. The Character decides to attempt activating it, as part of a Multi-Action, twice. Since the Metapower requires 🤞 for the Activation, and it is attempted twice – The Character must spend a total of 🤞 🤞 (one for each Activation). Since the rolls are two, a – 20% reduction is imposed on both rolls.  After rolling, one of the two rolls is unsuccessful. The Character decides  to spend additional 🤞 to reroll that roll (spending a total of 🤞 🤞 🤞 for that Multi-Action Metapowered activation). 

 

Extra Action

 

An Extra Action is a supportive roll to whichever secondary activity a Character wishes to commence during a Turn. The Extra Action slot allows the Character to perform activities that do not require much concentration or attention. The Extra Action can be attempted before or after a Character has attempted their Main Action during a Turn.

 

Additionally, a Character can always spend their Extra Action to de-activate any previously activated Metapower effect with ongoing Duration. A Character can also use the Extra Action slot to willingly reduce any number of ✔️️ from a d100 roll they make or remove any number of d10 dice results from a d10 Roll, in the event a Character wants to deliberately mitigate the efficiency of the effort. In order to do so, a Character can spend their Extra Action before attempting any other Action that the Character wishes to mitigate the efficiency preemptively. Alternatively, it can be done so after the other Action's has been attempted, before its result take place, provided that the Character has the Extra Action slot available.

 

Reaction

 

The Reaction slot is the only type of Action that can be attempted outside of a Character’s Turn in the Initiative order. Characters can spend their Reaction at any time during a Round in response to any Character’s Actions or Movement. The Reaction can take place before or after the Action of the other Character concludes or at any time during their Movement. A Character can spend their Reaction in response to their Action or Movement attempted by the same Character. In the event multiple Characters want to perform their Reaction during another Character’s Turn, then the Character with the best Initiative score attempts their Reaction first, followed by the one who has the second best, and so on. A Character cannot attempt a Reaction which requires spending any other Action slot, unless stated otherwise by the attempted roll’s description or by the Narrator. 

 

A Character can spend their Reaction to Evade incoming Strikes from other Character who have entered their space and threaten them with close-range attacks. During perilous situations a Character can spend their Reaction dive for cover, or get in front of another adjacent Character to save them from an upcoming danger. To perform these daring stunts of moving when it is their Turn to play, a Character must spend their Reaction, make a successful Reflexes roll, and have at least 1 of their Movement still remaining during this Round. If they do so, they fall prone and receive the Condition: Knocked Down, and they are able to move toward any one adjacent Hexagon.

Focused Action

 

Attempting an Action which requires extra attention, full concentration, or additional time to be activated, requires performing a Focused Action. Focused Actions have activations which require an entire Turn, or possibly even more in-game time. Attempting a Focused Action requires a Character to forgo their Movement, their Main Action and Extra Action slots, and even their Reaction slot, throughout the entire time the Focused Action is activated. In case a Character has already spent their Reaction during this Round, they cannot commit to a Focused Action. In case a Character spends their Reaction while in the middle of performing a Focused Action, then the Focused Action is cancelled. 

 

Focused Action activation time vary from a Full-Turn, a Cycle (in which case you will lose your Movement, Extra Action and Reaction twice) to activations which require a Character’s complete attention for up to 1d10 Hours. The Focused Action’s result commences at the end of the Focused Action’s activation, and only in the event the Character attempting it has not activated any other Action or Movement during that time. A Character can decide to stop their attempt at Focused Action, losing their progress in return, in the event they decide to attempt any other Actions instead (such as spend Reaction while performing a Focused Action).

Free Rolls

 

Free Rolls are additional rolls deemed unfit to take any Action slots during a Turn. With the Narrator’s approval, Free Rolls can be attempted even out of turn. Whenever the defending Character is involved in a VS roll, that roll is always considered a Free Roll for that Character and costs no Action slot. There is no limit to how many Free Rolls a Character can attempt during a Round, but the Narrator ultimately decides which rolls can be categorized as Free Rolls.

👣 Movement

 

Movement during Action Scenes represents the series of movements a Character is going to perform during a Turn. Movement is spent by moving around the area, using items and by interacting with the environment, such as when climbing higher ground in the terrain or when pulling levers, bushing buttons and so on. Some Item activations may require spending part of your Movement, while other Items, Metapowers or Combos might require spending the entirety of a Turn’s Movement. 

 

Movement is a number which is calculated by a Character’s Speed, Weight and Size.  A Character or vehicle’s Movement has a modifier of Speed, Weight and Size (described in detail below). A Character with no alteration in their Speed, Weight or Size will have a base Movement score of 10.

The Grid

 

The Grid is the visual representation of an Action Scene as seen from a top-down view. The Grid is composed of Areas, from the smallest Area: Hexagon [Area 1] Which represents an area of 2 meters (6.5 feet) wide, long, to the biggest Area: Planet [Area 16]. Moving from one Hexagon to any adjacent one costs one Movement. In case a Character is moving into areas with Terrain that is difficult to pass, moving to adjacent Hexagons might cost additional Movement. In some cases, a Narrator may state that each Hexagon represents a larger Area, and requires additional Movement to cross, in case the map used operates with scale. 

Areas

Spreading Movement

 

A Character can spend any number of Movement during their Turn and store the rest. Afterwards, they perform any Action slot they wish and afterwards, complete the remaining Movement available.

 

Additional Movement

 

During a Character’s Turn, a Character can forgo their Main Action slot to gain another Movement. The totality of a Character’s current Movement is added an additional time this way. A Character can perform their second Movement anytime during their Turn, same as the first one. A Character cannot perform an Additional Movement more than once each Turn. A Character cannot perform an Additional Movement as part of an Multi-Action. A Character cannot spend their Movement to gain an additional Main Action this way.

 

Getting Up

 

In case a Character has received the Condition: Knocked Down, or begins their Turn prone, down on the ground, then that Character must spend some of their Movement in order to get up. A Character may spend 5 of their total Movement to get back up.

 

Using Items

Using Items , operating Vehicles, and interacting with the environment requires spending Movement. A Character cannot use an item without spending the necessary Movement. Ⓜ️ Metapowers

  

·         Level (⏫) The level of the Metapower. Levels begin from level 1, the first level of an unlocked Metapower, and maximize to level 5.

Note: Metapowered effects above level 5 are called Omnipowered effects, and their mythical properties will be included in a future version of the game.

·         Energy Type (✨) The Energy Type of the Metapower. Energy Type dictates the Damage, Resistance, and other properties of an effect. 

·         Roll (🎲) Which Stat is rolled when activating this Metapower. 

·         VS Roll (🆚) Which Stat is rolled by the target(s) as part of a VS roll when activating this Metapower. Rolling a Stat as part of a VS roll is always a Free Roll, and the one who is defending does so passively, in most cases without them knowingly. In case a Character purposefully wishes their defenses to be down, they can choose not to attempt that roll.

·         Activation️ (⏱)  Which part of my Turn does it take to Activate this Metapower. The Activation could be always active, such in the case of permanent effects, or take any Action Slot (Main Action, Extra Action, or Reaction), a Character’s Movement, or the entirety of a Turn, in the case of Focused Actions. In case the Metapower entry has multiple effects, more than one Activation could be included into the summary of the Metapower.

·         Target (🎯) How many Targets, and which type are affected by this Metapower. In case the Metapower entry has multiple effects, more than one Targets could be included into the summary of the Metapower. Targets include both numerical values in the form of how many dice are rolled to determine how many targets are affected, which type of targets can only be targeted by this effect (such as Metanthropes, Humans, or Objects etc.), and a requirement of in which way the target needs to perceivable or detectable by the Character targeting (such as the target being Visible, Tangible, Detectable, etc.)

·         Duration (⏳) How long does this Metapower lasts. Some effects could have an Instantaneous Duration, meaning that they have an instant effect, that does not linger in any way in-game. Other effects could have the Permanent Duration, in which case they are activate all the time, unless the activator chooses, if able, to shut them down. In case the Metapower entry has multiple effects, more than one Durations could be included into the summary of the Metapower. All the Durations longer than a Round begin their countdown after the Turn they were Activated. For example, a Duration of a Cycle will end in a Cycle from when the effected was Activated, not when the current Cycle ends. In case an effect applies a Condition, then that Condition's Duration is equal to the effect's Duration. In case that effect's Duration is Instantaneous, then the Condition's Duration is equal to its base Duration, as seen, for example, here.

·         Range (📏) How far can you apply the Metapower's effect. Range is categorized in sixteen different Areas, from a Hexagon [Area 1] to the entire Planet [Area 16]. In case the Metapower entry has multiple effects, more than one Ranges could be included into the summary of the Metapower.

·         Area Effect (🗺️) What is the Range of the Area Effect if any, that is included into the effect. Area Effects use the same Areas with Range, although they refer to the size and scope of the Area Effect instead.

·         Area Effect (Type) Which type of Area Effect is utilized among Line, Burst, Aura, Hemisphere, and Sphere.

Additional Information

 

This segment provides Additional Information which is relevant to the Effect. Additional rolls that might be made, under specific circumstances, or further explanations of any Buffs or Conditions offered by the Effect, might be fully described in this segment.

 

Effect [Alt]

Some levels of Metapowers might include Alternative [Alt] Effects. When choosing to Activate a level of a Metapower which has an [Alt] version, it must be chosen before rolling which effect is being attempted, the main or the [Alt] version. The [Alt] version might have its own Range, Targets, Durations etc. Other than that, activating an [Alt] Effect functions the similar way with activating any other, main, Effect.

Combat is a part of an Action Scene which includes any kind of attacks, rolling for Damage, loss of Life and any other life-threating situations. Combat in Metanthropes involves Characters getting hurt, injured, or even dying.

 

💓 Life 

 

Life in Metanthropes represents a Character’s overall health, vitality, and will to live. Metanthrope Characters have a Life total of (100 + their Endurance score). Metanthrope Humans have a Life total of (50 + their Endurance score). Other Antagonist type Life totals may vary according to their specifics. Injuries of any kind reduce the Life total. Whenever a Character reaches 0 or less Life, that Character dies. Death of a Character is explained in detail in the last segment of this page.

   

💕 Healing

 

Healing increases a Character’s current Life. A Character’s Life total cannot be exceeded with excessive Healing. Some Metapowers offer access to direct and effective Healing, although nature works at much slower rate. To provide proper medical attention, a Character might need a medical kit containing bandages and so on, (depending on the Condition and the trauma) and the Perk: Medicine at a level according to the wound’s complexity.

 

 

  💥 Damage 

A Character’s Life is reduced by Damage. Damage is calculated by a total number of d10 dice rolled, plus any base number of Damage. Damage is caused by any harmful source, from an event like getting punched, to being ravaged by otherworldly forces. There are four Energy Types in Metanthropes: Cosmic, Elemental, Material, and Psychic. Each Energy Type causes its own type of Damage. Damage caused by Psychic energies is in the form of Psychic Damage and so on.

 

Damage is reduced by Resistance (read below for more about Resistance). In the event a Character is dealt different types of Damage simultaneously, calculate each of them separately, by removing the appropriate Resistance to each type of Damage.

 

How Damage and Resistance function

A Character attacks with a firearm which deals 4d10 + 40 Material Damage another Character who has 30 Material Resistance. The result of the 4d10 equals to 35. To that result is added the base 40 Damage of the Weapon. The total Damage is 75. The Target subtracts 30 due to their Material Resistance, and the final Damage received is 45. 

 

🛡️ Buffs

 

Buffs are positive effects received from Metapowers, Combos or Possessions. At the Narrator's discretion a Character can temporarily receive a Buff due to circumstances in-game, such as after highly successful rolls. Buffs are categorized to Buffs that increase the Characteristics or Stats of a Character, and Other Buffs which apply other type of positive effects. Buffs which increase the Characteristics or Stats of a Character are subcategorized into Buffs of the Body, the Mind, the Soul. Buffs of the Body include the Buffs: Fortified, Empowered, Hastened and Hardened. Buffs of the Mind include the Buffs: Inspired, Articulated, Alerted and Sharpened. Buffs of the Soul include the Buffs: Focused, Awakened, Determined and Enlightened. The Other Buffs include the categories: Additional Action, Cover, Detection, Environment, Enhance Movement, Immunity, Resistance, and Shift.

 

Multiple Buffs of the same name do not stack, and only the one with the highest numerical value is considered, the rest are ignored. Receiving the same Buff again simply refreshes the effect's Duration.

 

How multiple Buffs which increase the same Stat do not stack

A Character has received the Buffs: Empowered 2 (Power + 10%) Empowered 5 (Power +25%) and Empowered 1 (Power +5%). Only the highest Buff is considered, therefore that Character is affected only by the Buff: Empowered 5.

 

Buffs which have no numerical value, but rather are followed by a specific subcategory can stack with each other, even if they have the same name. One exception to this rule is the category of Buff: Shift. Only one Shift (the one with the highest level) can be active simultaneously. Read below for more about Shifts.

 

How multiple Buffs with different names can stack

A Character can be affected by the following Buffs simultaneously: Immunity (Slowed), Immunity (Skin Injury), Detection (Invisibility), Detection (Darkness).

 

For a complete list of Buffs, visit here.

 

Detection  

Detections allow a Character to perceive something others cannot. When activating a Buff: Detection, a Character adds a specific type of Character, Object, Dimension, Buff, or Condition to their sensory range. A Character can have any number of different Detections activated at the same time.

 

For a complete list of Detection Buffs:, visit here.

   

Immunity

 

Immunity offers immunity to medical conditions and specific effects. When Immunity is activated, it negates the effects of any Conditions of the same name or level, equal to or less than the number following the Immunity activated. A Character can have any number of different Immunities activated at the same time. In case a Character is affected by a Condition, and then receives Immunity to that Condition, that Condition is automatically removed.

 

For a complete list of Immunity Buffs:, visit here.

 

Resistance

 

Resistance in Metanthropes represents a shield that absorbs part or all of the Damage. Resistance is a static number that reduces the total amount of Damage dealt. There are four types of Resistances, one for each of the Energy Types (Cosmic, Elemental, Material, Psychic), each corresponding to their appropriate Damage type. After rolling for Damage, remove the appropriate Resistance number from the total Damage. Any remaining Damage is the only Damage the Character receives. Multiple Resistances to the same Energy Type do not stack, similarly to Bonuses – calculate only the highest amongst them.

 

How multiple Buffs which increase the same Stat do not stack

A Character has received the Buffs: Elemental Resistance 15, Elemental Resistance 30, , Elemental Resistance 20, Psychic Resistance 5, and Psychic Resistance 50. Only the highest Buffs are considered for each Energy Type, therefore that Character's is affected only by the Buffs: Elemental Resistance 30, and Psychic Resistance 50.

 

For a complete list of Resistance Buffs:, visit here.

  

💀 Conditions

 

Conditions, short for medical conditions, are negative effects received from injuries and trauma, physical or otherwise, inflicted by Metapowers, Combos, Possessions, or any type of attacks. Conditions are categorized to Conditions that decrease the Characteristics or Stats of a Character, and Other Conditions which apply other type of negative effects. Conditions which decrease the Characteristics and Stats are subcategorized into Conditions of the Body, the Mind, the Soul. Conditions of the Body include the Conditions: Bone Injury, Muscle Injury, Skin Injury, Asphyxiation, Burned, Bleeding, Diseased and Maimed. Conditions of the Mind include the Conditions: Wobbly, Confused, Disoriented, Disconnected, Pain, Fatigue, Hunger, and Sense Lost. Conditions of the Soul include the Conditions: Bewildered, Demented, Terrorized, Tormented, Amnesia, Probed, Infiltrated, and Unconscious. Other Conditions include the subcategories: Hinder Movement and Environment.

 

Multiple Conditions of the same name do not stack, and only the one with the highest numerical value is considered. Receiving the same Condition again simply refreshes the effect Duration.

 

How multiple Conditions which decrease the same Stat do not stack

A Character has received the Conditions Muscle Injury 2 (Power -10%) and Muscle Injury 3 (Power -15%). Only the highest Condition is considered therefore, that Character is affected only by the Condition Muscle Injury 3.

 

Conditions which have no numerical value, but rather are followed by subcategories can stack with each other can stack with each other, even if they have the same name.

 

How multiple Conditions stack

A Character with the Condition: Sense Lost ( Hearing), receives the Condition: Sense Lost (Vision). Even though they have the same name, the subcategory differs and that Character can be affected by both of them.

Bleeding 

At the end of each Round, a Character who has the Condition: Bleeding loses 1 Life per level of the Bleeding Condition.

Maimed 

A Character who receives the Condition: Maimed, depending on the level, and the location of the Condition, receives further Conditions and Penalties. Infiltrated 

A Character with the Condition: Infiltrated is a victim of someone attempting to influence their emotion, thoughts, or gain control over their actions and movement. A Character cannot be under the effect of multiple Infiltrated effect of the same level, only the latest applied is being considered.

 Strike

 

Strike in Metanthropes represents a Character’s physical attack made with bare hands, legs, knees, elbows, headbutts or via a Melee Weapon. The Strike’s unarmed Damage is of the Material Energy Type, and it deals 1d10 + the Character’s Power Score. A Strike requires spending the Main Action slot and is attempted with a Power roll. Since the Strike spends the slot of the Main Action, it can be turned into a Multi-Action. Strikes turned Multi-Action in-game translate into a choreography of attacks. A Strike turned into Multi-Action has the Damage of each successfully delivered Strike reduced by the amount of the Multi-Action’s reduction.

 

Reach is the Range limit of a Strike, and, in most cases, the Reach of any human-sized Character (Size 10) is the same Hexagon [Area 1] (within an area of two meters, or 6.5 feet close).

 

In addition to the Strike’s Damage, according to the accumulated  ✔️ ️ of the attack, successful Strikes also apply Conditions of the Body to their target. More accumulated  ✔️ ️ translate in-game into Strikes delivered with accuracy and precision, and therefore apply more threating Conditions, as seen in the table below.

 

 Evade

 

Evade is the answer all Characters have against Strikes of any kind. Only Strikes can be evaded, not any type of attack from Projectile, or Firearm Weapons. Evade costs spending the Reaction slot, and attempting a Reflexes roll. In case the evading Character is successful with their Evade attempt, then one  ✔️ is removed from all the attacker's Strikes against the evading Character are attempted this Turn. In case the attacker was successful ( 🟩 ) without accumulating any  ✔️, then the attacks are also successfully evaded. For every additional  ✔️is accumulated by the evading Character, an additional  ✔️is removed from all the attacker's Strikes against the evading Character attempted this Turn. 

 

Evade example

An attacking Character attempts a Multi-Action with three total attacks against a defending Character. The defending Character attempts an Evade, and accumulates  ✔️  ✔️  The three Strikes of the attacking Character accumulate the following results:   ✔️  ✔️ for the first Strike, 🟩 for the second, and  ✔️  ✔️  ✔️  ✔️ for the third. The defending Character's Evade makes the first two Strikes to miss completely, while removes    ✔️  ✔️  ✔️ from the attacker's third Strike. As a result, the attacker manages to hit the defending Character only once, accumulating a single  ✔️ .

 

Grappling

 

Grapple attempts are Strikes which if successful, have the result of immobilizing the target instead of dealing Damage. A Character who is under the effect of a Grapple receives the Condition: Immobilized, and cannot perform any Movement. A Character must declare their intent to attempt a Grapple before making any rolls. To perform a successful Grapple, a Character must attempt a Power roll, and spend their Main Action slot while being within Range, similarly to any Strike. This roll can be part of a Multi-Action and it can be evaded by the target. If the Grapple is successful, both parties proceed into making a Free Roll (does not spend any further Action slot) which is a Power (of the initiator) VS the Power or the Reflexes (of the target), chosen between them by the target. In case the second Power roll is successful, the target cannot spend any of their Movement during their Turn.

 

At the beginning of each of the Turns of a Character being grappled, that Character may now spend their Extra Action slot to attempt to escape the grapple. Then they proceed on attempting a Power or Reflexes roll (chosen by the grappled Character) VS a Power roll of the initiator of the Grapple. In case the grappled target is successful at this roll, the target escapes the grapple.

   

Specific Strikes

 

Specific Strikes may have different outcomes in addition, or instead of Damaging the target, such as disarming, tripping, feinting, pushing and more. In addition, Specific Strikes include complex grappling techniques such as body locks and other similar techniques. A Character must declare their intent to attempt a Specific Strike, and specify which one, before making any rolls.  Although a Character is free to attempt Specific Strikes without being proficient with them by having the Perk: Athletics at the appropriate level, it will trigger a Penalty, depending on the technique attempted, as seen in the following table.

Melee Weapons

 

Melee Weapons in Metanthropes refer to any weapons used in hand-to-hand combat, such as swords, spears, etc. Using Melee Weapons is considered a Strike and it can be subjected to Evade, similarly to any other Strike. Melee Weapons increase the Damage dealt in comparison to an attack made unarmed. The Melee Weapon Strike Damage equal to (the Weapon base + dice Damage) + the Character's Power score. Weapons do Damage of the Material Energy Type, much like unarmed Strikes, but they can also deal additional Damage of any other type as long as it is stated in the Weapon's description.

 

Melee Weapons are categorized into Bladed Weapons, which include all Melee Weapons with a bladed edge (such as knives, sword, axes etc.) and Blunt Weapons, which include all melee weapons with a blunt edge (such as hammers, staffs, and knuckles). The main difference between them is the Condition tables they use, according to the accumulated  ✔️ ️ of the attacker, as seen in the following tables. Although a Character is free to attempt to use Melee Weapons without having the appropriate Perk to use them, untrained attackers receive a - 10% Penalty when using Blunt Melee Weapons without having the Perk: Weapons at level 1, and a - 20% Penalty when using Bladed Melee Weapons without having the Perk: Weapon at level 2.

Projectile Weapons

 

Projectiles includes weapons that can be thrown, hurled, or launched at your target and require some physical activity and rely not just on aiming but on agility, creating a momentum or releasing a pulled string and so on. Examples could include throwing stars, bows, javelins and more. Projectiles (thrown) require a Power Roll, and their Range is determined based on how far a Character can throw an object, as seen in the table here,  and deal Damage equal to the Weapon’s Damage plus half your Power Stat (always rounded up). Projectiles (hurled) require a Reflexes Roll and deal Damage equal to the Weapon’s Damage . Falling Damage

 

When a Character, or an Object falls from heights higher than 1 Hexagon (2 Meters, 6.5 feet) then that target receives Falling Damage. The Damage is of the Material Energy Type and is equal to 1d10 + 10 Material Damage for each 2 Hexagons the target falls. In addition, the target receives Conditions based on the Strike Condition table: for each 10 total Damage received from Falling,  the fallen Character receives the equivalent of one level of Success (✔️) on that table.

 

How Falling Damage and Conditions are calculated

A Character free falls for 10 Hexagons (20 meters, 65 feet). The target receives 5d10 + 50 Material Damage. The result is 90 Damage: in addition the Character receives the Conditions of accumulating 9 *✔️ on the Strike Condition table (Skin Injury 5, Muscle Injury 4, Bone Injury 3, Bleeding 3, Pain 2, Maimed 1). 

 

It is possible for a Character falling from the air to reduce the Falling Damage by spending their Reaction slot and attempting a Reflexes roll. At the Narrator's discretion, the Character must be able to catch on to something, or find some way to reduce the impact of their fall. In the case the Character is successful, the Damage is reduced by – 10, and a further - 10 for each additional ✔️ accumulated by their Reflexes roll.

 

Death

 

Whenever a Character’s Life reaches 0 or below, that Character dies. Objects having their Durability reduced to 0 or below are destroyed. When a Character dies, all active effects, and active Durations of Metapowers they have activated, or were activated to them, end. 

 

In case a Protagonist dies, the Player owning the Protagonist can choose to spend one Destiny (🤞), to save them from dying. Doing so will return the Protagonist to 1 Life instead of dying. In case the Player does not have enough Destiny, or chooses not to spent them, the Protagonist dies. A Player can choose to spend multiple Destiny this way in case their Protagonist is about to die multiple times within a Round, for as long as they have the appropriate amount of Destiny to spend.

Roleplay

 

The combination of Background, Metamorphosis, Arc, and Regression influence heavily the roleplay of a Character. These features can be selected from premade archetypes, they can be randomly generated from tables seen below, or they can be unique and customized by players.  

Background

 

A Character's Background is who or what that Character used to be prior to becoming a Metanthrope. A Background can be a word, phrase or sentence that describes their pre-Metanthrope existence. It could be a job description, a title earned, an occupation, a Character's greatest skill or attribute, or anything else that is descriptive enough for that Character. Even the greatest of Metanthropes still might have humble beginnings.  

 

Metamorphosis

 

The Metamorphosis is a pivotal moment that defines how, when, why, and under what circumstances your Protagonist crosses the threshold from being a human to becoming a Metanthrope. It is a transformative event that shapes their identity. The Metamorphosis of a Metanthrope can take various forms - a single profound event, an ongoing process, a latent power that has existed since childhood, or a recent experience just before the beginning of the STORY.

 

Arc

 

Arc represents the fundamental concept, behavioral patterns, goals, daily agenda, and core beliefs of a Metanthrope. It defines how your Protagonist acts in various situations, establishes their hierarchies during conflicts, determines the ideologies they support in dialogues, and guides their use of Metapowers to achieve their objectives. The Arc embodies the archetype your Protagonist represents.

 

Successfully roleplaying your Protagonist's Arc in each Scene will earn you Destiny, based on in-game circumstances and your level of engagement. By roleplaying your Arc, you fulfill your Protagonist's destiny and follow the path they are meant to tread.

  

Regression

 

Regression is a fundamental aspect of a Metanthrope's existence, representing their connection to their human origins. It encompasses the reversion to human behaviors, quirks, and attachments that persist despite their ascension. Regressions can manifest as unique knacks, idiosyncrasies, nostalgic attachments, or self-imposed restrictions. It is important to recognize that Regression is not considered a weakness, as it can be a source of strength, adding depth, drama, complexity, and inner conflict to a Metanthrope’s roleplay. Every Metanthrope possesses a Regression, whether they openly embrace it, keep it hidden, or are unaware of its existence.

 

Roleplaying your Protagonist's Regression during each Scene allows you to fulfill their destiny and stay true to their path. By embodying their Regression, you gain Destiny based on your involvement and the circumstances in-game.

  

Summary

 

For the final step of a new Character creation process, a Player must include the finishing touches to their Protagonist, such as personal information, their appearance, and their personality.

Players are suggested to roleplay something they feel comfortable with, but also excites their imagination. Players can research different cultures, histories, accents, customs, ethnicities, and traditions to add as flavor to their Protagonist's roleplay. The Protagonist's appearance and clothing should be one that reflects the kind of story the Metanthrope is going to be involved in.
